Title: The year that was: 2013
Primary image caption: Music duo Tom Busby and Jeremy Marou at home on the Fitzroy River
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Alice Roberts
Subjects: Community and Society:Immigration:Refugees, Defence and National Security, Defence and National Security:Defence Forces, Event
Keywords: 2013, rain, storms, flooding, St Mary's Hospital, Duke of Cambridge, Prince William, Duchess, George, royal, Moura Hospital, Federal Election, Capricornia, Flynn, NDIS, Marlborough, John Smith, Talisman Saber, war games, US, asylum seekers, refugees, bulls, Rockhampton, Ockie, chimpanzee, Rockhampton Zoo
Words: The year 2013 began with a flood as Ex-Tropical Cyclone Oswald made its way down the east coast in January But among the devastation was a slither of hope with the birth of the world first hand cloned calf  The Royal Birth Soon talk in the town turned from the birth of the calf to the birth of a little prince  with many speculating what name the son of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge might take Moura fights From St Mary Hospital in London to the Moura Hospital in central Queensland the tight-knit mining community fought to save its medical services after the State Government threatened to shut it down But the town rejoiced when it was announced in April that the hospital would remain open and retain 24-hour emergency services NDIS Another contentious issue in the lead up to the 2013 Federal election was the National Disability Insurance Scheme For many in the central Queensland community it still remains unclear what the scheme would mean for them Springsure local Joyce Comiskey is the full-time carer for her 20-year-old daughter Lauren Joyce says she hopes that when the scheme is made available to her that they can choose where the funding goes so they can continue to care for Lauren in her home town A two-horse race Just north of the town of Springsure is the tiny community of Gindie where the annual small schools sports day is held The smallest school to take part in the event is the Lochington State School with just five students Some of the races on the day had just two students competing with the announcer calling it a two-horse race on the day Bush postie Another local character in Marlborough spends his days delivering mail to outlying properties John Smith says he travels about 2000 kilometres a week as a rural postie and sometimes that means transporting chooks in the cab of his ute for graziers who can't get into town Talisman Saber This year about 28000 US and Australian troops took part in the joint-military exercise Talisman Saber American Seahawk helicopter pilot Geoff Cruise says it the sense of adventure that he loves about his job Becoming an Aussie One central Queensland resident would count 2013 as a lucky year - Afghani refugee Mohammad Azad was reunited with his wife Kaniz and his two children after living in Australia for three years without them In February next year Mohammad will be eligible for Australian citizenship which he says would be a dream Busby Marou And this year has been a dream come true for local music duo Busby Marou with the release of their second album Farewell Fitzroy Tom Busby and Jeremy Marou say their latest album is about proclaiming their roots and saying goodbye to them at the same time The election Of course in September Australians headed to the polls to decide on a new government The federal seats of <a href=http//wwwabcnetau/local/photos/2013/08/26/3833469htm?site=&xml=3833469-mediarssxml#bigpicturepos?&section=news <http//wwwabcnetau/local/photos/2013/08/26/3833469htm?site=&xml=3833469-mediarssxml/>Capricornia and Flynn were captured by photographers in a series of images which highlighted some of the key issues for the two regions The bull rear-end An issue that had Rockhampton residents fired up this year was debate about whether to move the iconic bulls from the city streets to one location One of the reasons for the push by Capricorn Enterprise Mary Carroll was because visitors arriving to the city from the south were greeted with the sight of a bull rump But locals and visitors overwhelmed the ABC talkback line with calls for them to stay put Rockhampton resident Sam joked I'm a big fan of the bull and if they're worried about the hindquarters of them we'll put a head on either end of them Ockie Last month the central Queensland region lost one of its most famous locals Ockie the chimpanzee  Ockie died after suffering a heart attack and had been at the Rockhampton Zoo since 1986 A public memorial was held to commemorate his life Thank you ABC Capricornia would like to thank all our listeners readers and viewers for your support over 2013 and we can't wait to start the new year to meet new faces greet old ones and tell central Queensland stories

Title: Gippsland in 2013

Words: As the weather warms up and the end of the year draws closer ABC Gippsland takes a look at some of the big stories of 2013 through pictures Unfortunately it also was the setting of the Aberfeldy and Harrietville bushfires which ripped through parts of Gippsland destroying farming land houses and even taking a life The town of Seaton was burnt in the path of the Aberfeldy bushfire For many of those affected by the fires it took most of 2013 to pick up the pieces Trains stop Vline trains through to Bairnsdale ceased in March this year due to a signalling fault along the line Investigations into what caused it started in May A build up of rust was the culprit and six months after the line was first closed work began on repairs After the track was tested yet again it finally opened to trains Coal Seam Gas Over a year ago Gippsland landholders began to notice the growing number of exploration licences for unconventional gas mining covering farming properties across the region As the interest from companies exploring for these resources has grown this year so too has the opposition to unconventional gas mining from a grassroots level Federation University The announcement of the merger of the Gippsland campus of Monash University and the University of Ballarat under a new regional university shocked students and staff earlier this year The transition to Federation University took up most of 2013 the new university will commence in 2014 ICE concerns Community members turned up in their hundreds to a forum in Warragul held in September to discuss the methamphetamine ice There has been growing concern over use of the drug this year and the facilities needed to treat addicts Flooding Gippsland did experience some flooding this year mostly centred around Traralgon although there were many rural areas that got very soggy The rain caused more water to flow into the Yallourn mine causing more headaches for its operator Energy Australia; this year a report was released into its flooding in 2012 Yallourn power station Yallourn was also in the news this year for a year long industrial dispute between Energy Australia and The Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union Workers were locked out of the plant for months until an in-principle enterprise agreement was finally struck between the parties Federal Election The Gippsland electorate has existed since Federation and has been held by the National Party since 1922 the McMillan electorate was formed in 1949 and has swung between Labor and Liberal over the years This year Federal election provided an opportunity for some new candidates to challenge the incumbents Clive Palmer put candidates up for his party and Ricky Muir ran for The Motoring Enthusiasts Party As a Coalition government won the election and the National Party Darren Chester was reinstated in the seat of Gippsland as Russell Broadbent was for the Liberals in McMillan GSI collapse 2013 brought bad news for the investors of Gippsland Secured Investments The company went into receivership in September and froze withdrawals to about 3500 account holders A bailout attempt by a number of Gippsland business leaders failed to recapatilise the lender and keep it trading As the end to 2013 draws near ABC Gippsland had the chance to send heavy metal band Anient into the next round of the ABC Exhumed competition and we also bid farewell to one of our much loved Breakfast presenters Gerard Callinan

Title: Counting raindrops
Primary image caption: Bureau of Meteorology duty observer Brendan Bradford releases a balloon at the Rockhampton airport
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Alice Roberts
Subjects: Weather, Weather:Cyclone, Weather:Rainfall, Weather:Storm
Keywords: Bureau of Meteorology, disaster, emergency, ABC, Brendan Bradford, weather, rain, floods, cyclone
Words: They head to work in rain hail or shine and spend their days counting the raindrops Rockhampton observer Brendan Bradford says the office is one of the last in the state to manually release balloons that send information back to the bureau about wind speed wind direction temperature and humidity We can get a remote balloon launcher there one in Mackay that may be utilised here and there another one in Longreach that may be utilised here in the future but at the moment we're still releasing them manually says Brendan And it takes away a fail safe as well I think sometimes manually if you're doing a balloon like that then there nothing else that can go wrong you're just walking out and letting the balloon go You lose that element of something mechanically going wrong or some of the automated systems not working A hydrogen balloon is released every six hours and because Rockhampton meteorological office is located at the airport they have to be careful of passing aircraft We check in with air traffic control every time we release a balloon and at the moment there a lot of helicopters around so we just have to check says Brendan Sounding the sirens Bureau of Meteorology weather services manager Richard Wardle says the bureau speaks to the ABC more readily during times of emergency to ensure residents are getting the most up-to-date information He says the bureau works closely with emergency services during major weather events We ensure we're getting the best information out there before it happens what we expect to happen and the uncertainty of what may or may not happen and then the emergency services can go ahead and make decisions to try and mitigate against any severe weather he says And prior to the severe weather season along with Emergency Management Queensland we do a tour of regional centres including Rockhampton Mackay Townsville and Cairns where we give a seasonal outlook; what we expect the severe weather season to be like Weather nuts Brendan says his personal interests led him to a career in weather I'm not a weather nut but I did a science degree many years ago and it just fit in he says I was always interested in the weather and interested in sailing and surfing and things like that as well so it just a natural progression to move into the weather bureau He says ex-Tropical Cyclone Oswald was one of the biggest weather events he been involved in We had record rainfall events around here and that was quite a big deal for the office and obviously for the community as well he says He says the bureau is increasing the number of forecasting roles so there plenty of opportunity to work in the industry There not too many observing roles but it a great lifestyle you get to work in lots of different parts of the country and count the raindrops he laughs The year 2013 Richard says the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is currently neutral but residents shouldn't become complacent Last summer we had a neutral ENSO and we had ex-Tropical Cyclone Oswald so neutral does not mean benign and that really our message here he says He says Australia is looking to have its hottest year on record and central Queensland has not be exempt from the warmer conditions We are expecting our days and nights to be warmer on average so we're expecting a warmer summer he says I think we'll be talking about 2013 being the hottest year on record and when we do have hot years we do have heat waves Richard says this summer is expected to be a dry one

Words: Just as the bushfire recovery process was underway in 2011 the park was again hit with a downpour of 370 millimetres of rain in 24 hours Landslides now scar the parks well known mountains such as Mt Oberon where walking and driving tracks were closed for many months during the clean up process Silt washed down Titanium Creek in the valley below Mt Oberon has left a trail of deadened trees and made a path for pest species spread In the north of the park trees burnt in the 2009 bushfire were killed by the silt of the 2011 floods Down on the Prom beaches estuaries have widened with the inundation of water flow and created tidal pools At Whisky Bay Parks Victoria moved a walking track when the shifting soil uncovered new Aboriginal cultural heritage sites Forty new sites thousands of years old  containing Aboriginal artefacts have been discovered in surveying post floods Brett Mitchell ranger in charge at the park and flood recovery coordinator says events such as fire and flood can't be helped in a natural environment He says positives such as the discovery of new connections to the park cultural past are just one of the good things to come of the floods; even though the landscape has changed the park remains a treasure Apart from the slips the vegetation has come back strongly and is regenerating really well so I think it still it iconic self I think it still as spectacular as ever Brett says

Words: Floodwaters washed them about three kilometres from their home property and all efforts to recover them including ferrying them out failed A novel plan to create a 25-metre bridge of carpet allowed the cattle to walk out to dry land at low tide Rescue organiser and neighbour of the cattle owners Caroline Ferris said time was quickly running out to rescue them They had plenty of feed but had only a small pool of fresh water Mrs Ferris said the ordeal lasted several hours and was exhausting for both the rescuers and the rescuees The cattle were pretty stressed they weren't marching two by two like Noah Ark They were baulked by the orange construction tape (lining the carpet) they didn't want to go in we let them stand there for a good half an hour and think about it and just look Owner Wendy Harlin from Childers says she had two months of sleepless nights worrying about her pets She says she won't let them go back on agistment in North Bundaberg and may have to give them a good bath No they're going home for a bit of love and cuddles I have shampooed them before (they get dirty) in the Childers red soil The fifth cow is still somewhere on a series of interconnecting islands Residents and fishermen are urged to look out for her around the Barubbra Island/Moore Park area but not approach because she quite cranky Seven more of the Harlins cattle from the same herd were also swept away and are still missing The rescue group had appealed to the local council and RSPCA for help which both said the issue was out of their hands and responsibilities

Words: The Australian Sugar Cane Railway in Bundaberg flood-prone historical precinct the Botanic Gardens is cleaning up after floodwaters swamped locomotives and gutted buildings Secretary of the Australian Sugar Cane Railway Ross Driver has been coordinating working bees and fire crews from as far as Beaudesert to clear out sheds the one-kilometre track and trains It a lot worse than the 2011 flood Ross said This time it was well above the roof I would say 16 feet (48 metres) higher We knew the flood was coming and we lifted everything higher than the 2011 flood but as it worked out there was no hope We lost a lot of historical records in there and it was really sad Things like timebooks we had timebooks going back to 1985 We were fortunate as the secretary I had taken out the minute-books just previous to the flood because we're actually writing the history of the society One special machine a Valdora diesel hydraulic locomotive from Nambour tracked the flood levels very clearly in water lines up it body Finally it (the water) ended up at the top of its windows Ross said We were very fortunate that the water didn't get high enough to get through the exhaust stack the big filters on it held a lot of the mud and the silt out (The Sugar Cane railway) is important as far as the history of Bundaberg goes because all the locomotives that we've got here pertain to the sugar industry When we do get going again we'll get that steamer out the front and we'll blow that whistle and I'm sure all of North Bundaberg will hear it going and they'll know we're at least coming back to a bit of normality The damage bill of hundreds of thousands of dollars is not covered by insurance because Ross says the Society received no payout in the last flood event He says sugar railways will always have to deal with floods but the society will consider relocating training rooms and machinery

Primary image caption: Valla Rural on Feburary 23

Words: Wild wind and heavy rains battered the mid north coast and north coast on Friday and Saturday The low has tracked slowly from the NSW far north ranges to the south-west during Saturday Residents have reported rainfall of up to 200mm in a 24 hour period Wind gusts reached 93 km/h at Coffs Harbour at 6pm on Friday Earlier wind gusts reached 126km/h at Cape Byron John Donohue from Ballina Marine Rescue had a bird eye view of the wild weather from the communications tower as 110km/h strong winds battered the windows late on Friday They're probably the strongest I've experienced in my 15 years here in the communications centre he said We're also experiencing very big seas of 11 metres; that was about 1030am Waver rider buoys offshore from Byron Bay and Coffs Harbour recorded waves as high as 12 meters on Friday The SES has been kept busy attending to hundreds of rescue and emergency call-outs as a result of flooding fallen trees and damaged rooves The body of a 17-year-old Bonny Hills boy who went missing during the height of the storm was found on Friday morning It believed he was waist-deep in floodwater collecting golf balls with friends before being sucked into a storm water drain Mid North Coast Police Inspector Kim Fehon says it was a tragic accident The most important message with the terrible weather that we are having at the moment is for all people to stay away from water affected areas this was a tragic outcome and we really don't want it to happen to anyone else The death toll for the event rose to 2 when a man body was recovered from a car in floodwaters near Grafton on Saturday afternoon Five Japanese tourists had to be air lifted to safety on Saturday morning after a nightmare ordeal The men were driving through water south of Lismore at approximately midnight when their car slid down an embankment and was inundated The car rolled and they had to grab what they could and swim to the bank We screamed for helpcrazycold and dark For five hours the men sat cold and wet and waited At dawn they walked to the nearest property and raised the alarm The resident contacted 000 and the Police referred the task to the SES Now in the care of DoCS clothing and temporary accommodation has been arranged This is a stark reminder for people to never drive ride or walk through flood waters The system is losing strength as it tracks south west and the region is not expecting any large rain falls in the next 12 hours For emergency help in floods and storms ring your local SES Unit on 132 500 in an life threatening emergency call 000

Title: Remember this? Newcastle's 2012
Primary image caption: Martin Ballangarry, OAM, visiting from Nambucca, took part in the Lake Macquarie NAIDOC celebrations.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Theresa Rockley-Hogan
Subjects: Arts and Entertainment, Community and Society, Disasters and Accidents, Disasters and Accidents:Fires
Keywords: newcastle hunter 2012 remember year in review 1233 abc storm bushfire super moon floods olympics paralympics knights jets coal-seam gas NAIDOC shark attack figs laman st
Words: There were wild storms bushfires and shark attacks But also inspiring Olympians and Paralympians gifted surfers and amazing astronomical events Let look back at 2012 in the Hunter including the highlights for 1233 ABC Newcastle In February drama soon arrived with the controversial Laman St fig trees finally chopped down amid heated and emotional protests that made national news bulletins After years of dissent and millions of dollars spent by Newcastle City Council the area around Civic Park was unrecognisable after the historic trees were removed Meanwhile footy fans were beside themselves with anticipation of the coming NRL season with super coach Wayne Bennett leading the Newcastle Knights and the deep pockets of the Tinkler group at the team disposal Alas the high hopes weren't to be realised with inconsistent performances resulting in the Knights missing the finals In March Surfest also benefited from an influx of Tinkler funds enabling it to upgrade events and lure top surfers from around the world With its highest prize-money ever on offer 800 competitors took part at Merewether Beach tackling some impressive waves Brazilian Willian Cardoso won the men event with Sally Fitzgibbons the women winner Soon after Upper Hunter residents were relieved by the dramatic capture of notorious fugitive Malcolm Naden in a remote homestead near Gloucester after seven years on the run In April the big wet continued with the coast experiencing its wettest week in a year But boating and sailing enthusiasts weren't deterred with Port Stephens hosing a major regatta in stormy seas and a superboats event attracting thousands to Newcastle Harbour In May astronomy buffs and keen photographers were out in force to see the supermoon an extra-bright and large full moon that provided some stunning images especially around the cliffs and surf of Newcastle coast In sport Knights fans were disappointed when captain Kurt Gidley suffered a season-ending injury and the Wallabies played an historic first-ever rugby union test in Newcastle losing to Scotland in atrocious conditions As winter set in June again brought wild weather to Newcastle and the Hunter Waves were breaking a couple of kilometres off the coast and the massive swell flooded Newcastle Ocean Baths and caused erosion at local beaches The surf was a dangerous place for other reasons when a man escaped uninjured from an attack by a 2m great white shark as he paddled his surf ski off Redhead Beach At 1233 we were inundated by stunning photographs as we held our first Portrait Prize which was won by Sarah Jozefiak with an atmospheric black-and-white self-portrait And the astronomy buffs were out in force again this time for the Transit of Venus In July more amazing pictures came from NAIDOC celebrations in Newcastle and at Lake Macquarie and the 1233 Challenge Cup contest was won by the New Lambton Starlings girls soccer team Newcastle also cemented its reputation for taking out reality-tv contests with Maitland locals Brad and Lara winning record prize money in The Block Coal-seam gas protests were in the news in August as Fullerton Cove locals fought to prevent exploratory drilling In the lead-up to the local government elections local developer Jeff McCloy announced his candidacy for Lord Mayor And at the London Olympics Lake Macquarie sailors Iain Jensen and Nathan Outteridge sent Wangi Wangi into a frenzy of celebration when they won gold In September the world attention turned to the Paralympics with another Lake Macquarie sailor Liesl Tesch winning gold and champion wheelchair athlete Kurt Fearnley bringing home bronze and silver Teenager Maddie Elliott from Port Stephens also excelled The bushfire season got off to an early start with a blaze in inaccessible scrub at Dudley coming dangerously close to homes The local government elections saw Jeff McCloy installed as Newcastle new Lord Mayor as well as the first female mayor of Lake Macquarie Jodie Harrison In early October more wild weather blasted the coast with snow on the Barringtons as NSW experienced an unseasonal cold snap At the Civic Theatre 1233 celebrated another successful Night at the Wireless The Newcastle Jets announced new marquee signing Emile Heskey and with his goal-scoring prowess got off to a great start to the season The hot weather finally kicked in as November arrived with a bushfire in the Edgeworth area threatening homes and having to be water-bombed Meanwhile the 1233 Movocastrians devoted themselves to growing moustaches for Movember and Newcastle Council tried to avoid another fig debacle this time at Hamilton And the Hunter was at the centre of national attention when abuse of children by Catholic clergy in the region and allegations of cover-ups from a local detective led to the Prime Minister announcing a wide-ranging Royal Commission As the year wound to a close home-grown former billionaire Nathan Tinkler who is now worth considerably less was dealing with financial problems and legal cases plaguing a number of his companies In December things only got worse for the mining magnate with the Australian Tax Office moving to wind up the Newcastle Knights the Jets and Hunter Sports Group over unpaid tax of $27million However HSG stated it would pay the money owed as soon as possible and it would be business as usual for the two teams As Christmas approached the State Government was seen as Santa by some and the Grinch by others when it announced Newcastle rail line would be cut at Wickham After literally decades of indecision the government has now promised $120million for the project which will see the rail corridor retained for green space eight new crossings and increased bus services from a transport interchange at Wickham

Words: When Prue and Anthony Cliff heard news that the Avon River was expected to peak on Tuesday the Stratford couple began preparing their home and dairy farm for the worst Thankfully the flood waters stayed in the paddock but as Prue explains when you live on a flood plain you can never be too prepared The couple have seen floods before the last being the 2007 floods when their home was inundated with a few inches of water The house was severely damaged by the 1990 floods This time around it the couples dairy farm that been damaged most Anthony says it will cost a minimum of $300000 to repair damage to the farm But although the damage bill is significantly less than the $15 million spent on fixing the farm after the 1990 floods it still means a lot of hard work for the couple I reckon it will be about a month of hard labour Anthony says It could have been worse though he says Prue agrees It a good chance to have a good spring clean Prue says staring at her ripped up carpet and stacked furniture     Prue Cliff Stratford dairy farmer explains how to pack up a house in case of a flood

Words: The Rex Theatre in Charlton has come a long way from initial fears that the cinema would never re-open thanks to the generosity of volunteers charities and plenty of hard work But after more than a year of tears false starts and plenty of hard work the curtain was finally raised in a gala event A full house was on hand to celebrate the efforts of volunteers and various charities who all joined forces to enable the facility to re-open And while the historic building itself has been repaired in appropriate fashion state of the art technology has been added including 3D capable projectors and extra speakers for surround sound The result is an iconic theatre that can continue to serve Charlton and the surrounding areas for years to come For more information on the Rex and its volunteers visit the website      Retired ABC local presenter Dave Lennon talks about his love of historic cinemas

Words: A tow truck driver says he is amazed by the number of people who continue driving through floodwaters while a Main Arm woman whose station wagon was swept off a causeway urges others not to make the same mistake Jamie Hedditch says most of those vehicles were swept off flooded causeways in the Byron Shire hinterland It pretty disappointing to think that people keep risking their lives and other people lives by driving into floodwaters he says It amazes me where people end up in their vehicles places I wouldn't even dream of taking a truck let alone a car Particularly up this valley (near Main Arm) people are well aware of the flood risks and what these causeways do I know people who have lived up here for years and years and they still take risks One of the vehicles Mr Hedditch retrieved at the weekend belonged to Main Arm resident Eva Petersen Driver speaks out Ms Petersen says she was wary of crossing the flooded causeway outside of Main Arm on Saturday but decided to do so after watching three other vehicles make it through So then I followed them and just as I was going across about eight or 10 feet upstream there was this broken branch lodged with all this debris and there was an almighty crack and the branch just splintered into pieces and this wave of debris and water just hit the car she says Then it was history because the stream was flowing quite rapidly Ms Petersen managed to open her window and climb onto the roof of the vehicle before jumping into the floodwaters and making her way to the edge She says she will never drive through water again It was really terrifying and it was really quick it happened so quickly she says I would just say never even try it it really deceptive You watch other cars go through you think it fine and it not Ms Petersen vehicle has been taken to a wrecking yard     Tow truck driver Jamie Hedditch

Title: Tropical Cyclone Heidi just another wet season in the Pilbara
Primary image caption: Carolyn Day said, 'This creek runs past our homestead and continues on into the East Turner River. These were taken from our veranda. The creek is still rising and it's still raining, the wind has dropped a bit but there are still some strong gusts'
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Submitted | Byline: Carolyn Day
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Cyclones, Weather:Cyclone,
Keywords: TC heidi,cyclone,port hedland,emergency,flooding,disaster,north west,pilbara
Words: There was more trepidation ahead of Tropical Cyclone Heidi than you might expect from the Pilbara So you might think that category two cyclone Heidi that passed almost over the top of the tough iron ore town of Port Hedland would barely rate a mention But surprisingly this was Hedland first cyclone since 2007 when Severe Tropical Cyclone George hit the region where it hurts taking three lives Less well known than the big east coast cyclones Larry and Yasi category four George tore through Port Hedland before ripping up mining camps and cattle stations So there were more nerves than usual in the North West as Cyclone Heidi crossed the coast at almost the exact spot the deadly Cyclone George did five years ago Hedland resident and ABC reporter Elise Batchelor described the strange effects the 130 kilometre per hour wind gusts were having on her home The manhole cover in ourceilingIt was flapping like a wobble board Rolf Harris style and then just flew up and disappeared into the ceiling Power was cut to over 3500 homes as the eye of Cyclone Heidi crossed the coast ten kilometres east of Port Hedland Fears of a dangerous storm-tide did not eventuate as the cyclone slowed on approach to the mainland and crossed after the midnight high tides But with over a hundred millimetres of rain dumped on the area local flooding was an issue The Bureau of Meteorology issued flood warnings for coastal streams and river systems Chris a boilermaker at Nullagine said they've had over 200 millimetres of rain It rained solid for 28 hours nowThere like huge puddles everywhere; there not much dry land here he said But early assessments have found no major damage a couple of roofs were blown off and quite a few trees and power lines were blown down The stoicism and hardiness of the region returned with the light of day and the realisation that damage was minimal We're getting a fare bit of rain but as long as the winds don't pick up then I think we should be pretty much right said Graham Boyd the principal at Yandeyarra Remote Community School 100 kilometres south of Hedland The Great Northern Highway was closed for less than 24 hours to stop people driving into the eye of the storm But with the passing of Heidi the main road north was promptly reopened Chainsaws will be ringing out across what will be hot and humid days ahead in Port Hedland Horizon Power have crews working to restore power Heidi is destined to become a barely remembered event in a part of Australia where cyclones are a way of life

Title: A trip back in time, down the Murray
Primary image caption: Construction of Lock 1 in Blanchetown, c.1920
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: supplied | Byline: Discover Murray River
Subjects: Business, Economics and Finance:Industry:Transport, Business, Economics and Finance:Regional Development, Community and Society:History, Community and Society:Regional
Keywords: murray history construction river murraydarling basin paddlesteamer dock lock paddleboat transport wharf bridge pioneer droughts, floods, paddleboats, barges
Words: The Murray Darling Basin Plan has to work within a highly regulated river system in its pursuit of improving river health but what do we know about the origins of the locks and weirs that have so tamed the rivers? They're all mixed up says Roley who responsible for the operation and maintenance of the Mildura Weir and Lock 11 - one of several key regulators of the Murray Darling river system Opening up an old photo album he finds an old typed document This is a resume from the chief engineer says Roley he was applying for another job in 1938 Although these archives are fairly accessible to anyone looking for them not a lot has been done on the history of this time There isn't a great deal on record about this period says Helen Stagg - who recently completed a Masters in oral history on the topic Of course you have to do a literature review and there precious little out there to review Ms Stagg own ancestry is tied up with the history that surrounds the construction of Murray River regulators with her mother growing up at several lock construction sites Her work has led her to interview surviving members of these communities like Max Pearson who was born during the contruction of Lock 1 at Blanchetown It took four years approximately to build a weir and a lock says Mr Pearson and when that four years was up all the houses were pulled down and carted to the river bank put on the barges; and the paddlesteamers then would tow it to where the next lock was to be built Mr Pearson says he is the youngest surviving employee to ever have worked in the construction of the regulators on the Murray - starting at 15 with carpenters on the Goolwa barrage My first 16 years of life was spent on the banks of the river Murray he says Ms Stagg also interviewed Marge Francis who was born on Lock 9 in 1924 where her father worked as a static engine driver Ms Francis story correlates with Mr Pearson Wherever the men went they had to build their own homes because only the bosses had homes supplied for them says Ms Francis We were lucky I suppose my father had a 1924 Chev so of course the house was on top of the car as we moved So what was life like in these communities? Mr Pearson says the education was limited to primary level with over a hundred children in the school with one teacher but he says his memories of life along the river were positive We played cricket we played footballused to play a lot of marbles and generally we would do what children in other areas would be doing he says Ms Stagg says the social life of the lock communities was very rich with the school doubling as the dance hall or picture theatre They had at least a weekly dance she says Films would come in on the mail truck and one of the local men would put on the film - he had the skills to run the projector Ms Francis says that the communities were essentially brought together because of economics Like everything else you go where the work is she says When you look back on it it was an experience of its own This experience is one that Max Pearson wants to hold onto as long as he can To care and to share with other people that was the only way we were able to keep our existence going he says We have made it a part of our lives to go back to these areas and try to relive the type of towns that they were     A trip back in time down the Murray

Primary image caption: The number 967 engine sits idle at the Valley Rattler workshop in Gympie
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC | Byline: Ross Kay

Words: In January we found ourselves isolated from a number of the outlying suburbs including a major outlying industrial and residential suburb called Monkland manager Jim Walker said The Valley Rattler had a high level bridge over the top of the floods so we put a little rail motor in action During the two and a half days that the shuttle service was operational the service carried 3000 passengers including emergency workers involved in the clean up as well as supplies of milk bread medication and five tonnes of meat Due to the reliable build of the rail motor there were no breakdown or repairs issues even though it was put to the test with little notice You've got a 60 year old vehicle which should be an antique I suppose doing a job that is really meaningful It helped out the town and kept the economy going in some circumstances Jim said Now as we approach the first anniversary of the flood Jim and the Rattler team are prepared to jump in and assist if they are again needed But it not just a token gesture it now forms part of Gympie disaster management plan Following what we did during that flood they  the Gympie Disaster Management Group  have now incorporated the Rattler so we are part of the counter disaster planning for Gympie Which is a difficult thing to do considering the staff of the Rattler except some maintenance staff are all volunteers So when disaster strikes is it hard to ask more of people who are already donating their time? President of the Valley Rattler Tony Hallam said that not the case It funny some people will grumble but they say yes and that was the case during the floods Tony said It was fully volunteer run people knew they had a job to do and they just got stuck in Co-ordination of the services getting the message out driving the rail motor and loading and unloading the supplies A lot of volunteers gave 110 per cent When it comes to the future of the Rattler this icon of the area is tightening its belt and getting on with the job of tourism and promoting the region Like all tourist industries we're facing a time of slow recovery We've had to trim back expenses and we're running on a very tight budget at the moment but I think a lot of tourist industries will be doing the same Tony said We found that in the initial period after the rattler got going again local were patronising the service more We also found this during the school holidays Reviewing the figures October 2011 was the first month this year where we had an increase in passengers compared to the same time last year That really is good news and a shot in the arm for the Rattler

Title: SES volunteers prepare for Summer
Primary image caption: SES volunteers in training
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline:
Subjects: Community and Society:Community Organisations, Community and Society:Volunteers, Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Incidents, Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Planning
Keywords: ses, brisbane, abc, 612, emergency services, volunteers, queensland, floods, cyclones, news,
Words: In an emergency SES volunteers are on some of the first on the front line but how do they prepare in their down time? But when they're not responding to storm flood or road related call outs volunteers spend their time training to respond to such emergencies and making sure their equipment is ready to go when they get the call Western Group SES in Brisbane western suburbs has over 90 members who attend a training session every Monday night Acting Group Leader Fiona Manning says volunteers give up a lot of their time to attend each week Our training night is from 7pm-10pm so we get three hours of training but beyond that we have to keep our equipment maintained and ready to go so that when we get a call we can just get in the vehicles and go out and do what we need to do We have teams coming in earlier than training from about 530-6pm Fiona says the extra time allows volunteers time to maintain and organise equipment administration and training Volunteers are constantly being trained in a wide range of basic areas such as first aid search and rescue map reading and vehicle and equipment operation before moving on to more specialist training to assist them in deailing with road crash rescues vertical rescues land searches water rescues and team leadership Ahead of the storm season we are currently focusing on a storm damage refresher course especially useful for our new members The Western Group SES run their operation from a depot at Toowong but during the midst of the Brisbane floods one of their busiest times they along with many homes and businesses in the area had to evacuate due to the rising Brisbane River Twenty one volunteers from the crew spent 14 hours straight moving valuable and expensive equipment to Mt Cootha Botanical gardens which became their temporary base during the emergency We spent a whole night and morning evacuating as much gear as we could so we could remain operational during the whole flood period she says Senior volunteer Peter Healey says remaining operations throughout the evacuation was a huge thing to achieve We managed to move a quarter of a million dollars worth of equipment; vehicles stretchers tarpaulins generators lights the whole box and dice In April the team moved back to their Toowong training spaces after many hours spent cleaning and re-painting buildings that indundated with up to 16 metres of water at the floods peak Up to 30 new members have joined Western Group alone helping boost the Queensland count to 7200 registered SES volunteers who've responded to numerous events during the past year and committed more than 175000 operational hours to the frontline Peter says members from Western Group have responded to several serious events this year which at times can take a toll on volunteers  We've had members deployed to Far North Queensland after Yasi members deployed to Gratham for searches; we've had people on Daniel Morcombe searches We haven't stopped it just been one of those years Despite some South East Queensland communities taking the last 11 months to recover from January weather events the SES are again preparing for another wet season which Peter expects will keep them busy His warning to residents Check your gutters make sure you've got a radio spare batteries torches and medications because when Mother Nature comes a knocking there isn't a lot of time to start thinking For more information about how to prepare for storm season you can visit the ABC Wide Bay Emergency website     What do SES volunteers do when they're not responding to emergency calls?

Title: Chowilla's black box woodlands still waiting for the big wet
Primary image caption: Black box woodlands like this one on the Chowilla floodplain are at risk of dying out under the current draft Basin plan.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Charlotte King
Subjects: Environment:Biological Diversity, Environment:Conservation, Environment:Environmental Impact, Environment:Environmental Management
Keywords: floodplain flood chowilla conservation wetland environment vegetation blackbox redgum drought
Words: Vast black box woodlands along the recognised lower Murray conservation site the Chowilla floodplain may be at risk of dying out under the proposed Murray Darling Basin plan Dr Ben Gawne one of the authors of the CSIRO review says this is because such large volumes of water are required to push water up into the higher areas of the floodplain Even if that water was available within dams it would be very difficult for managers to release that volume of water with the system configured as it is at the moment he says A lead researcher into the Chowilla floodplain has warned that abandoning the site could have unforeseen consequences for not only the floodplain but the Basin itself Dr Anne Jensen PhD focused on the three key vegetation species on the floodplain the black box red gum and lignum and their water requirements; she now works as an independent consultant for the University of Adelaide It would be a brave decision to decide to abandon 70 per cent of the floodplain One of the major concerns from a scientific point of view is that we're not sure what would happen to the abandoned section; it quite a large area and we would end up with a sort of no-man land between the Mallee country and the riparian zones that we might be able to save We're not sure what would then happen to the soils the salt balance the water balance what would happen to the animals It'd be a real unknown which could have consequences we don't even haven't even thought of yet Dr Gawne says it ultimately up to the broader community not scientists to decide whether they are comfortable with the potential loss to biodiversity There was always going to be some sort of compromise between the level of environmental protection and the economic use of water One of the big steps forward in this process has been that it is now quite explicit what environmental assets will be protected under the Basin plan and what the social and economic impacts will be It is now possible to negotiate that trade-off but there is a risk around that - it that level of risk that people need to be comfortable with and say well given the economic changes that are going to be required are we prepared to take a risk that not looking after those black box woodlands will lead to some loss of biodiversity or some cascading damage to the rest of the Chowilla floodplain he says     Chowilla black box woodlands still waiting for the big wet

Words: Ranger in Charge of the Grampians National Park Dave Roberts says crews have been working for the past seven weeks to reinstate the walk to the bottom of the falls It about 300 steps down and some sections of the path are less than a metre wide You can't get any equipment in or out in terms of heavy handling gear everything needs to be winched from above with pulleys and cranes or manhandled down using physical labour It a real constraint for us at the moment - particularly with the weather we've been having around the Grampians region in the past three or four months just being able to work in that environment down there has been really difficult for us It was hoped the walk would be open by now but Mr Roberts says the delay is due to public safety concerns With the absence of the bridge and no real safe crossing point to get to the other side of the creek there really a lot of issues down there with slippery surfaces inappropriate falls from heights - particularly with the rock ledges The site can usually cater for 100-150 people There a lot of flat area  across the creek  people used to stand on the bridge and get their views back to the waterfall to take their photos At the moment with the area that available you're probably looking at only 15-20 people being able to fit at the bottom of the falls and even then their experience is quite limited because they're almost in the wash of the falls and they've got water spraying in their face But replacing the bridge crossing isn't as easy as it might seem given its location at the bottom of the gorge Mr Roberts says it will take a fair amount of engineering to get the old damaged bridge out let alone to bring another one in Despite the wet cold and difficult conditions the crews are working as fast as they can to restore temporary access across the creek by way of a stepping stone bridge but even that is hard going Because the site is quite challenging for us and there a lot of water moving through the crossing at the moment we're making sure we're using rocks that are big enough not to get washed away Some of the rocks these guys are moving are up around the tonne or 1500kg and they're physically having to find them winch them chain them turf them into position and it not an easy environment to work in While the stepping stone crossing will make it easier for groups of people to enjoy the site it won't be an all weather easy access crossing The conditions associated with the steppingstones are variable When the water authority are releasing lots of water from Lake Wartook there a fair chance those stone steps will be covered with water We're appealing to people who are visiting the area to really use their common sense we'll have signs up expressing our recommendations around when and when not to use the stones Eventually a new bridge crossing will be built but it will take some time for the design and the logistics to be worked out Mr Roberts says he hopeful the walk will be open for the spring school holidays     Dave Roberts Ranger in Charge of the Grampians National Park

Words: The people of Warmun have been welcomed back to their community four months after it was destroyed by flash-flooding Situated near the dramatic landscape of the Bungle Bungles the community of Warmun has made it mark on the world Indigenous art scene For Indigenous art lovers the Warmun Art Centre was a place of pilgrimage For the community it was a successful industry for Aboriginal people with a paucity of opportunities But the flood in mid-March 2011 took all that away Houses were destroyed and personal possessions white goods and cars were strewn across the landscape Most of the people of Warmun had to be relocated to emergency accommodation in Kununurra The move from a remote community to a relatively large town brought all sorts of social challenges But just four months later the community has been rebuilt enough to welcome the residents back to their bush home ABC Kimberley was there to capture the sights and sounds of the big welcome home Kimberley Mornings Vanessa Mills presented the program from the community and spoke to the people celebrating a House Warmun party     House Warmun Party

Words: It been called the Cardy Flood Recovery Bed Push and involves one man a handmade bed and a long walk along a regional road Back in February an amount of rain fell in parts of Sunraysia over one weekend that equalled the average yearly amount Cardross was one of the hardest hit communities in these record floods with the main access route Dairtnunk Avenue under water for weeks the school closed and the football clubhouse still unusable Four months on from the floods John Burfitt - a resident of neighbouring Red Cliffs - has devised a light and fun campaign to bring the spotlight back to the affected residents of the area some of which still have not returned home Making his way from Cardross Primary School to Langtree Mall in Mildura John Burfitt is hoping to raise funds for those in the community who after being hit with record floods are in true need of it If you didn't get to drop some money in his box as he pushed his way along the route you can deliver a donation to Bev Marks Beds on Fifteenth St in Mildura or send a cheque or money order to Red Cliffs Salvation Army PO Box 72 Red Cliffs 3496     The mirth behind the berth Peter Crisp sends off Jhn Burfitt on his Cardy Bed Push

Words: A media storm swept through the flood-affected goldfield towns of Clunes and Creswick as Prime Minister Julia Gillard announced $500million to assist Victorian communities still recovering from floods While it is a welcomed announcement community members are asking why it has taken so long Many roads and bridges around Clunes and Creswick were severely damaged by floodwater in September last year and in the January and February floods The funding was originally announced in the aftermath of the floods but a National Partnership Agreement was only signed with the State Government this week A similar agreement was reached with the Queensland State Government following the January floods and Cyclone Yasi Ms Gillard defended the time it had taken to reach an agreement with the Baillieu Government We've been working cooperatively with Premier Baillieu we will continue to do so I don't make any apology for making sure that we've got the best oversight we can have to get value for money Communities that have got damage like this to repair want to know that everything happening so every dollar being spent and getting the maximum value Heather Gervasoni runs Creswick takeaway store Krackerjacks which was flooded twice in less than four months She says business is getting back on track but questions why it has taken so long for the Federal Government to provide funding I think that good I'm glad they've done that but it been about six months after the first flood and to me I just think that a bit late It just taking forever for the recovery of all this flood business Clunes Caravan Park owner Les Eastcott says there are still major problems with roads and drainage around the town My response will be very positive I think that any money that available to be spent on infrastructure in Clunes which is my interest is going to be very important Ms Gillard also announced joint funding of grants towards cleanup for small businesses and primary producers worth up to $25000     Clunes and Creswick residents react to Prime Minister Julia Gillard flood funding announcement

Words: Destructive paths remain where landslips - some more than one kilometre long - made up of trees debris and boulders have cleared everything in their path Sections of many roads were either damaged or covered in debris It will be months before some of the major tourist attractions within the park are open to the public again Popular parts such as the Mackenzies Falls Venus Baths and the Zumstein area will remain closed however about 15 walks will be open across the Halls Gap Northern Grampians and Southern Grampians Parks Victoria ranger David Roberts says it will take years to get many parts of the national park back to a high-use standard but some significant walks will be open for the holidays The Silverband walk to the Silverband Falls and the walk from Mackeys Peak to the pinnacle are really important for us Vic Roads western region director David Oullivan says cleanup works along Grampians Road and Northern Grampians Road are nearly complete however he says the repairs to these roads will take at least six months We've removed debris from most of the roads with the exception of the northern part of the Silverband Road In terms of tonnage  it  around about 13000 tonnes which involved 1300 truckloads The Grampians Road and the Northern Grampians Road are much longer term prospects I'm afraid as is the northern part of Silverband Road Mr Oullivan says while some new landslips have occurred months after the original slips Vic Roads is still on budget We still stick pretty much to our original estimate of about $25million worth of work that needs to be done and the only variation that I can foresee is the state of Silverband Road when we uncover that northern part of the car park The park would normally attract about 20000 visitors at Easter For a full list of what is open and closed visit the Vic Roads websites     Vic Roads and Parks Victoria explain the existing damage in the Grampians National Park

Title: Flocking to Lake Hindmarsh
Primary image caption: A male and female chestnut teal
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Rebecca McLaren
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Environment, Environment:Endangered and Protected Species, Environment:Water
Keywords: Lake Hindmarsh, Outlet Creek, Lake Albacutya, floods, Jon Starks, Bird Monitoring, waterbirds
Words: It not just holiday makers and water skiers following the flows in the Wimmera River to Lake Hindmarsh it the birds fish and frogs Among them is Jon Starks bird monitoring program coordinator at the Wimmera Catchment Management Authority who visits the lake each month to record waterbird numbers and the variety of species Jon surveys from six points around the southern shore of the lake and he estimates the lake is currently about half full with water levels still rising When the water first started flowing into Lake Hindmarsh in September 2010 Mr Starks says there were small ducks coots and moorhens but as the water has kept flowing so have the birds kept flocking back As the reeds and things have grown up around the edge here at the southern end of the Lake it provided habitat for some of our migratory birds like reed-warblers and also little grassbirds It become fantastic habitat for a lot of these birds What I've noticed is that as the lake has filled and as things like fish have come into the lake - and fish will be spawning in this newly flooded lake - that there been a change in the birds that have come here Initially a lot of the birds that came here were birds that feed on algae and plankton and things which are usually the first things that will start their cycle when a dry area is newly inundated So initially I was getting a lot of ducks like teal black ducks and things; then as the fish arrived and fish numbers increased I was starting to get the fish eating birds - I was seeing herons around the edge (they'd also be eating frogs and things which have also responded) but also cormorants and pelicans And it seems many birds are making the most of the boom conditions around the lake and breeding late into February Mr Starks says he can hear the calls of the reed-warblers as the males are still advertising their territory And because of this new flush of water in from the January rains there going to be a whole new breeding event They might be able to get three or four clutches out this season but next season with no flood water they may not breed then for another two or three years 1967 I think was the last time pelicans were recorded breeding here and there are pelicans here now that have moved in because of the water and fish levels It'd be really interesting to know if pelicans are going to breed again in Lake Hindmarsh Jon says the million dollar question remains how do birds know when a dry lake suddenly fills for the first time in 14 odd years? I wish we had the answer to this but millions of years I guess of evolution has taught birds that their whole cycle is geared to this There must be cues in the environment for rain and things that birds know and they'll come into these areas and arrive in quite large numbers and breed and then the water goes and the birds go While most humans are less than impressed with the increase in insect activity brought on by the recent flood events it is great news for the birds We're watching here a lot of dragon flies although the adult stage is terrestrial the young are an aquatic form mudeyes as we know them so they need water to breed A lot of water beetles and water boatmen will just be going through real boom times out of this water Some of the ducks like musk ducks they'll be eating aquatic invertebrates and of course there'll also be lots and lots of yabbies out there too now Regent parrot Turning our backs to the lake for a moment we focus on the red gums around the lake to look for the regent parrot an endangered species that frequents Lake Hindmarsh We don't spot any today but Jon says the parrots are doing quite well at the moment and there has been a fair amount of breeding activity in recent months Regent parrots they're a resident species they don't undergo these long migrations or nomadic movements they're here all year round But when you get a lot of rain like we've had in the Wimmera recently and the vegetation has responded to that rain there a lot more seeding of the shrubs and the trees and things that they feed on which gives them the opportunity to undergo good breeding efforts There been a lot of occupation of hollows of the big old red gums that are around the shore of the lake here and a lot of them have been occupied by regent parrots and there breeding going on here at the moment I'm not sure what the population would be it would only be in the thousands they are a listed species in Victoria and they happen to like the red gums around Lake Hindmarsh and Albacutya and they're also up into Wyperfeld National Park and along the river and they're doing particularly well at the moment which is great Outlet Creek As water levels in the lake continue to rise the water is moving ever closer to Outlet Creek and Lake Albacutya and while we may still have some time to wait before the lake reaches the estimated 378 gigalitres (almost 90% full) needed to flow into the outlet the water flooding into the northern end of the lake is creating new feeding grounds for even more birds Jon says that in the area of more recently inundated ground to the north more shore birds are being recorded than in the south Birds like black-winged stilts and lapwings and plovers tend more to be congregating around the northern end where they're picking up on that new flush of growth of algae plankton and the insects and things that respond to that newly wetted ground A lot of the invertebrates worms and insect larvae and things that were in the ground when it dry are now suddenly brought to the surface because there water there and a lot of birds will be moving in and feeding in response to that It been about 15 years since the lake was this high says Jon which means trees and shrubs have grown in the lake bed and are now inundated as the water moves north It part of a natural process those trees and shrubs that can survive this water will flourish and those that can't will die off This water will hopefully cause a new flush of growth of red gum seedlings or box trees trees that need a flood event for them to germinate It really weird to see water underneath wattle trees and pine trees reeds growing in amongst woodland shrubbery and to see ducks flying overhead and frogs calling in among them Frogs Also making the most of the return of water to the Wimmera are the frogs There will be an awful lot of frog breeding activity all across the Wimmera at the moment not just around the lake but all the little pools the old farm damns that have filled up little swamps and things in paddocks Several species of frogs have been patiently awaiting the return of water hibernating underground One species called the spadefoot will actually dig a hole into the ground sometimes a metre deep and they'll actually hibernate it a process called estivation where they secrete a little mucus membrane a little envelope to trap moisture around them They can be underground for years and years just waiting for the next time that lake fills When they detect the soil moisture is wet around them again it time to emerge They will call very quickly for a mate after emerging they probably won't even have time to do much feeding cause water in those conditions generally doesn't stay on the surface very long so there only a very narrow window for them to attract a mate for the males for the females to spawn and then for the tadpoles to go through their cycle But not all frogs have the luxury (if you can call it that) of a mucus membrane to protect them from drying out Frogs need moisture they're not like reptiles that can survive drying out Some of the larger frogs like the pobblebonk we're hearing here they're quite a large frog they can be almost as big as a tennis ball sometimes they will hide under leaf litter in the soil In the absence of being able to burrow into the ground like the spadefoot they will look for areas that have moisture trapped cracks in the ground underneath logs and things where moisture might be trapped is where these frogs will sit it out but because they don't hibernate they can't survive for many years but when you get a flood event that flood can bring new frogs in We visited the lake during the day so it wasn't the best time to listen for a variety of frogs most will only call at night but we could hear the distinctive bonk sound that gives the pobblebonk its name Jon says there are 13 different species of frogs in the Wimmera and they can often be heard calling after rain The little froglets which are only an inch long the common froglets they're quite widespread There are a few threatened species in the region a large frog called the growling grass frog is still to be found in some parts and they have been turning up now in places where they haven't been heard for a long time because of the water There a tree frog Peron tree frog which is also called the maniac frog because it got a laugh like a homicidal maniac and they've been heard calling in some areas of the Wimmera River nearby So what been really fantastic for those interested in frogs with all this water around is we're just hearing frogs all over the place where we haven't heard them for a long time We're privileged to be able to witness the return to the full circle of life in Lake Hindmarsh celebrating not only the return of fish and frogs but also the return of the waterbirds that will eat them We can only wait and see if we will be celebrating the same thing for Outlet Creek and Lake Albacutya in the near future Jon Starks bird monitoring program coordinator Wimmera CMA

Title: Emotional strain rises as the floods subside
Primary image caption: Steven Smythe at his flooded Deakin Avenue property
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Charlotte King
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Health:Mental Health,
Keywords: floods mildurafloods vic
Words: It been two weeks since a deluge of rain threw Sunraysia into flash floods and some are still coming to terms with the emotional stress of losing their house property and livelihood Basically the septic water has stagnated I've got pets out there that have drowned and I haven't been able to collect them yet he says His foot has got an infected cut from the first attempts to pump water from his property He has also been electrocuted by faulty flood affected power points and has incurred burns from an explosion in his gas stove I pretty much lost all my hobby crop out there and the entire house contents shed memorabilia I'm a bit of an auto collector so stuff like that you can't buy off the shelf Steven says He was offered sandbags and help to set them by emergency teams when the flooding began because he was incapable of heavy lifting with a back disability Since the flood waters engulfed his house Steven wife has had to stay away from the property due to illness and emotional distress Steven visits the Mildura flood recovery centre everyday I enjoyed the hamburgers cause that about all I was eating and I'm getting some counselling he says Steven insurance provider has offered him accommodation and to pay for his expenses in the meantime but he doesn't want to leave his property I was still fearful I had power on food in the deep freeze that I couldn't afford to replace I have pets three dogs and was ten chooks now a couple cats all that stuff it just impossible to move away he says I may talk happily and bright on the face of it but underneathshe not he adds There are plenty of stories like Steven It typical of some of the complex issues that individuals and families are dealing with says Pat Timmons General Manager of Mallee Family Care and coordinator of the personal and counselling services at the Mildura recovery centre There has been a steady flow of people checking in and asking for advice and direction from the counselling services at the recovery centre he says Environmental health issues usually require people to leave their houses Pat Timmons says according to levels of damage some can return but others will be waiting quite a while For a lot of people in the local community their families are dispersed so that normal support level that you get from families and friends in the neighbourhood just isn't there That where personal support and counselling services through the flood recovery centre just provides that extra person to them if they need to have a chat if they need to work through something or if they're feeling isolated with this overwhelming issue he says However people are feeling its common reactions to an uncommon event he added For those seeking emotional support and counselling services in the Mildura area the flood recovery centre is located at the Rural Ambulance Victoria Building opposite the Irymple Swimming Pool on the Calder Highway Irymple     Steven Symthe

Words: It been a wild week of weather in the Goldfields and across the Western Desert Two people had to be rescued from a vehicle drive stranded in window-deep water and 30 homes were evacuated Storm clouds gathered across the Goldfields across the weekend with heavy rain over Kalgoorlie-Boulder causing Gribble creek normally a trickle to rise to road level on February 16 The worst was still to come The town of Laverton in the northern Goldfields received 100 millimetres of rain over twenty-four hours  causing the town roads to flood on February 17 cutting off the town and threatening some homes Over 200 mine workers were evacuated by air and FESA are working to ensure supplies to the remaining residents It not over yet The Bureau of Meteorology warnings remain in place into the coming weekend for likely flooding in the Goldfields Eucla and Interior For the latest warnings see wwwfesawagovau     Trevor Tasker District Manager of FESA for the Goldfields

Title: Kerang still recovering from floods

Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Mildura Swan Hill | Byline: Jenni Henderson
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods,
Keywords: floods, recovery centre, Kerang
Words: People living on properties once isolated by flood waters near Kerang are now starting to seek assistance using any means they can to get into town There a lot of sadness a lot of anguish and the fact that the rain is still looming people are really unsure as to what going to happen she says Those coming into the centre are looking for financial assistance and feed for stock but there is also a large demand for alternative accommodation Colleen says It been a very trying prospect for those involved in that because its running short we're running out of accommodation for these people she added There are still accessibility problems for people in the areas of Murrabit Wandella Koroop Benjeroop and Koondrok trying to get into Kerang Kris a centre volunteer says day to day life for those affected by the floods is far from returning to normal The farmers seem to think they might have two years sour farm those are the words I'm hearing now so I guess it going to take a long time she says Kris says she is lucky her home escaped damage and that she has had something to do to take her mind off problems around town I feel really blessed that I've been able to be useful and the second part of that is that I haven't been feeling useless I've been seeing an awful lot of people who don't know what to do with themselves she says Kris has seen numbers drop in those coming into the centre from approximately 200 a day at the start of the floods to now less than 100 The centre is open this week on Monday and Thursday from ten in the morning till three in the afternoon I guess it calmed down a bit Personally I think it good we need to get back to normality We need lots of resources in behind the scenes to get people through of course Kris says     Kerang Recovery Centre

Words: Ron Saunders who has been at the centre of Kerang agribusiness sector for decades says that though the Kerang township was bracing for the worst it is the surrounding rural properties that have suffered the most devastation Belying this tragedy he says is the fact that some farmers are able to bring a sense of humour to the situation It is on the farms that the most devastation has been seen says Ron But against all odds some farmers are still able to have a laugh I had one phone call during the height of the flood - a bloke complaining that he wanted to claim on his foriage sorghum crop because it was three foot under water and wouldn't grow According to Ron there have also been countless situations where farmers are helping each other out for instance providing space for livestock so that dairy farmers can continue to milk their cows There are some really good acts of kindness out there - it just mind-boggling     Kerang Ron Saunders on the effect of floods on rural properties
