Title: Volunteers at the heart of Charlton recovery
Primary image caption: Bitumen lifted up and rolled out like a red carpet
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Rebecca McLaren
Subjects: Community and Society:Charities and Community Organisations, Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Health:Doctors and Medical Professionals,
Keywords: Charton flood volunteers sue-anne hackett, kay cossar, field clinic donations, avoca river
Words: About eighty per cent of Charlton suffered damage in the floods of January 2011; many had only just finished rebuilding after the lesser floods of September 2010 We are escorted in the local Teddywaddy CFA truck so as to safely traverse the badly damaged local roads and occasionally where the road is no more Large potholes have been gouged from the roads and in some places the bitumen is sliced through with layers so clear it looks as though someone has simply taken a neat slice of sponge cake At one property we find a section of bitumen that been completely lifted from the road turned around and laid out neatly like a red carpet into a paddock Fences lie curled up in strange places or struggle to stand under the weight of debris left behind and large cavities have been carved in the sandy soils near the road In town mounds of damaged furniture and carpets are still being piled in front of homes fences are missing and the height of the water is marked by a layer of sediment left on every building and in every garden Despite this bleak picture the volunteer coordination centre and the shire hall are abuzz with activity as people try to pick up the pieces and move forward Local cafe owners Neville and Robert had only just finished replacing carpets and cleaning up after the September flood but this flood event has completely destroyed the fittings in the cafe and this time around everything will need to be replaced While they admit there was a slight hesitation before they dug in their heels and said yes we will stay we will rebuild it seems as though most of the business community has decided the same and will eventually reopen The local medical team is working from a field clinic set up inside a basketball court with services such as chiropractic and massage therapy on offer in the squash courts Charlton GP Registrar Dr Adele van der Merwe says all patient records have been able to be brought to the field clinic to enable a continuity of care We can do everything we need to do  here  patients can come in we've got all their notes it not all a new process for them to continue their management Each family that is able to return home and each business that reopens is a boost to the morale of the local community Community volunteer coordinator Kay Cossar says that while volunteer fatigue is a real concern the town is bolstered by the stream of volunteers and donations arriving from all over Victoria Australia and the world! And managing those donations since Friday the 14th of January is local Sue-Anne Hackett Ms Hackett spends every day matching families in need with donated goods to help get them home again or at least make them as comfortable as possible in their temporary accommodation On the day I visit her she searching through the large (and boiling hot) storage shed of donations for a camping lantern for one family who are still without power more than two weeks after the flood She also trying to organise a generator to be delivered to them later that night I have had some families walk in that door and they've been in tears the first thing I do is give them a hug and let them know that they're not alone Ms Hackett says the community is still in need of furniture such as wardrobes drawers and mattresses as well as small electrical appliances People that are now going back into their homes realise the toaster  doesn't work  or the kettle or electric frypans I'm sure some families have one stuck in the back of the cupboard that they don't use any more - we'd love to have it! While there been little rest for anyone in Charlton since the river began to rise those working hard to rebuild the community aren't looking to call it quits anytime soon When you start a mammoth project like this you can't walk away halfway through it and there are still a lot of families that need help says Ms Hackett We're still trying to find accommodation for some residents although family and friends have just stepped up to the mark in an incredible way and opened up their homes hearts wallets to people that have been staying with them We're just so blessed to have such a tight community here in Charlton everyone has just stepped up to the mark from tiny little children to the elderly and it just so rewarding to be a part of a special special community     Charlton resident Sue-Anne Hackett volunteering in the donation centre

Title: In photos: Benjeroop's inundation
Primary image caption: The hay shed at "Murray Meadows", in Benjeroop, where a header is stored
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Audience submitted | Byline: Sandi Semmler
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Incidents, Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Rural:Agribusiness, Rural:Agricultural Crops
Keywords: floods, benjeroopfloods, benjeroop, vic,
Words: Benjeroop Sandi Semmler says she is not expecting things to return to normal anytime soon in Benjeroop where record floods have caused significant damage to her property We had locals who families had been farming in the area for generations telling us we'd be fine and wouldn't be affected! But Ms Semmler says that when the water approached the reality of the situation set in When we started seeing the volume of water heading for and surrounding Kerang we realised this was something very different Thankful that their house itself was not inundated Sandi Semmler says that she doubts her family will be able to live at home for some weeks; she sent through these photos to ABC Mildura Swan Hill something any local is encouraged to do We have two kids who attend the Murrabit Group School and at the moment the road to Murrabit is cutso we'll have to rent a house on the other side of that for them to get to school when it does start Following the township inundation Benjeroop Hall has been the focus of the local community who have fought to keep the floodwaters from impacting there If you come up here you can only visit by boat says Rod Homewood who has been acting as team leader for the State Emergency Services (SES) in the small township of Benjeroop north-west of Kerang They've got a little tinnie out here if there are too many of us we get our bottoms wet! With a second sandbank levee now in place a metre of water is being held back from the hall water which stretches beyond vision After laying around 2000 sandbags over the past two days with other volunteers Rod Homewood says he is fairly confident the hall will stay protected To send through your photos from the floods visit our Facebook

Title: Donald lends a hand
Primary image caption: The floodwater in Donald, looking towards the bridge over the Richardson
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Supplied | Byline: Trevor Campbell
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Planning, Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Disasters and Accidents:Relief and Aid Organisations,
Keywords: Floods, donald, relief centre, riverside motel
Words: When floodwaters raged through Charlton in January 2011 residents were evacuated to nearby Donald where sporting rivalries gave way to community support and comfort Ms Williams says when they arrived about midnight there were people just pouring in Fortunately for many of those people Kim and Geoff own a local hotel which is currently closed and they were able to volunteer about 20 mattresses and blankets to help supply the relief centre  We  basically didn't leave for nine days says Ms Williams If someone required clothing or something we'd organise to get clothing to them; or if they had special dietary needs we had to make sure that they were taken care of But Ms Williams says the biggest job she had while volunteering in the centre was talking to people Trying to help them deal with it without saying the wrong words to them that was a challenge for me a really big challenge In the first few days they didn't do a lot they were in shock they didn't talk much But after two or three days the shock wore off they started to get agitated and wanting to get back to Charlton to see what was going on They had no idea what they were going to discover when they got back there Finding beds food and support for Charlton residents weren't the only challenges thrown at the relief centre volunteers in Donald that week We were isolated no one could get in or out of Donald which meant when the evacuation centre started up we had basically no outside help and no one in Donald had experienced running an evacuation centre Our Red Cross and local Council were absolutely fantastic with leading the rest of the community with what to do and how to handle things We had the power off for three or four days as well so we were dealing with 170-180 evacuees with no power and we were getting very low on water pressure It went off really really well considering all the adversities that were thrown at us at the time     Donald resident Kim Williams

Words: A local DJ from Lake Boga Yvonne has had to put off her Saturday night party show until she is told it is safe to return home; but when you're told to go she says you go For the past week her Lake Boga house has been empty - aside from an independently minded cat - and will be she says until she is told by authorities that it is safe to return Until that time she - along with a handful of others growing smaller by the day - has been making use of the facilities at the Swan Hill relief centre at the Indoor Sports Stadium on Gray Street When you're told to go you pack up and go she says Acknowledging that there are clear down sides to staying in a relief centre Yvonne puts a positive spin on the situation; one area where she has no complaints she says is the number of policemen present a presence that makes her feel secure and - she is careful to note - is often easy on the eye Not all the centre guests were happy about the organisation of the flood relief however Also from Lake Boga a couple who wished to be referred to simply as Julie and John said they were instructed through an automated message last week that access to Swan Hill via the Murray Valley Highway would be lost in a matter of hours When the route remained open for the rest of the week they became frustrated saying that they were told to evacuate unnecessarily; they have now returned home     Life inside the Swan Hill relief centre with Yvonne a Lake Boga DJ

Title: Rain reshapes Grampians National Park
Primary image caption: It's incredible those few trees are still standing
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Rebecca McLaren
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Disasters and Accidents:Storm, Environment:Conservation:National Parks, Human Interest:Animals
Keywords: Grampians National Park, vicroads, parks victoria, david Roberts, David o'sullivan, rains, floods, wallaby
Words: While the widespread flooding across much of western Victoria has devastated homes businesses and agriculture the force of the water is truly evident in the Grampians National Park Areas of the Park previously hidden by thick scrub are now clearly exposed and roads that have carried millions of tourists through the Park for decades simply don't exist anymore Ranger in Charge David Roberts says around 280mm of rain fell in just three days in mid-January 2011 creating landslips overflowing creeks and a massive amount of mud Huge boulders were released from high escarpments and felled large trees rushing through existing small creeks smashing roads bridges and walkways Being escorted through a small section of the Park reveals an unrecognisable landscape It looks more like images I have seen of forests decimated by logging In Halls Gap businesses were inundated when the Stony Creek flooded the central business district and holiday makers were evacuated to Stawell Police tape remains where the creek broke its banks and even though it is school holidays the carparks are empty and the town is quiet Halls Gap is open for business and the main road is open but without the attractions of the National Park it seems visitors are hesitant to return VicRoads and Parks Victoria are working together to secure access and repair tracks and roads but for now the entire National Park remains closed Mr Roberts says a few areas of the Park will open next week but it will be long time before large areas of the Park can be made safe What we've tried to do is put in place a staged approach to opening We're looking at opening up some smaller walking tracks around Halls Gap to provide a bit of a tourist focus to Halls Gap The northern part of the Park up towards Mt Zero and Hollow Mountain has been less impacted by the damage so we've had crews up there trying to open up those areas as well And we've also had crews right at the southern end towards Dunkled just assessing and making sure we can provide some access to the southern end Mr Roberts says many of the Grampians walking tracks may be severely damaged but it impossible to get in and assess them at this time  In  the well known and well loved Wonderland area a lot of the walking tracks are suspected to be severely damaged if not completely gone That includes not only the stone steps and the walkways but the infrastructure of the bridges and boardwalks associated with those It will also be some time before the effects of this rain event on the native fauna will be known The flooding has impacted on both habitat and food sources for native residents of the Park Some of those are not so well understood areas such as aquatic invertebrates and the freshwater system explains Mr Roberts The good news for the Park is that the Brush-tailed Rock-wallaby population is safe and sound We sent a helicopter with the telemetry up two days after the rainfall event and they flew over the site and actually picked up all animals plus one other that they thought they'd lost For the roads within the National Park though it will be a long time before all access is able to be restored David Oullivan from VicRoads says the Grampians repair work is likely to constitute its own project worth many many millions of dollars We're talking at the moment with Parks Victoria about prioritisation says Mr Oullivan The Grampians Rd North Grampians Rd and the road to Wartook are all absolutely devastated with rock-slips which have come all the way down the mountain and taken the road out in a big way We actually require some new bridges because there have been new waterways created in the rock-slips It will be a very long term project Parks Victoria VicRoads and Halls Gap Tourism are working together as they face a long recovery for the National Park and wait for visitors to return We've got some assessment to do both from the infrastructure point of view but also our natural values and also our cultural values our indigenous and non-indigenous heritage says Mr Roberts While visitors may never see exactly the same things they remember in the Grampians National Park these geological changes have exposed new formations and there will be new experiences and new attractions in the Park The Park in areas that we have come to love has changed but we'll be looking at new experiences and opportunities for people     David Roberts Ranger in Charge Grampians National Park

Words: People have come from across the state to lend a hand to flood-affected farmers Most of the volunteer work involves cleaning and fixing fences so farmers can get back to business People have been coming from Melbourne and across regional Victoria to help Blaze Aid with their program in the rural town of Bridgewater north-west of Bendigo Farmer David Collins has a massive cleanup ahead Not only has he lost fencing but hundreds of his sheep were swept away and the bodies of some remain embedded in trees and fences  We  lost close to 700 merino ewes washed away and a lot of fencing damage David has been overwhelmed by the support of strangers He says two of the volunteers were from New South Wales and were starting a trip around Australia It quite amazing We had a couple come today that heard Macca last Sunday on the radio and were heading to South Australia for holidays To turn around and come back and do some pretty dirty and sort of hard work on a fence line for people you don't know it pretty hard to comprehend really Frank Coghlan has 3000 acres along the Loddon River and flood waters tore down most of his fences In normal times we had 120 paddocks which were secure for stock and now we've got four he says Many farmers across regional Victoria will now need to quickly erect fences to secure the livestock that has been spared from the floods Geoff Foletta has come from Kilmore to help clean and rebuild fence lines He says volunteering is part of the Australian spirit and is calling anyone else with spare time to come along That what Australia is all about helping your mates There a lot of physical damage but there also a lot of emotional damage and not only are we repairing fences etc we're giving the people that have been affected a huge uplift For information on volunteering or for property owners who would like assistance with fences visit the Blaze Aid website or call 0466 348 408 You can also register to help in other parts of the state via the Volunteering Victoria website     Blaze Aid volunteer effort

Title: Clarence River flood stories
Primary image caption: This land sits just outside the Grafton levy.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Local | Byline: Renee du Preez

Keywords: flood, Clarence River, emergency, infrastructure damage, road building, recovery, clean-up
Words: The Clarence is in flood recovery mode Families isolated by flood water are arriving in town farmers are starting the arduos task of cleaning up road and infrastructure assessments are being made and everyone is looking out for dead fish floating in the mightly Clarence While the clean-up continues many residents are wondering how long it will be before they're faced with a second flood in 2011 The weather bureau has warned the Clarence and all flood prone regions of the North Coast that there a 70 percent chance of major flooding before May The community is placing bets on when it will come Sue and Jeremy Challacombe who've got a reputation for superb strawberries are hoping the major investment in time and money they make in April planting 30 thousand plants is not washed away by a May flood After watching an old 57 metre levy wall over-top and flow like Niagra onto their farm in this latest flood they're hoping the community will be prepared if the Grafton levy can't hold the next flood surge The lower Clarence pubs in Brushgrove Ulmarra and Harwood are back to business having chalked up another flood experience Allan Tutt has seen four floods in 14 years as the publican in Harwood He got a timely story to tell about the disasterous infections that can come from exposure to flood mud The Salvation Army are always on alert when people are in need It was 50 or so stranded freight truck drivers who needed the Salvos this time June Richardson tells of the logistics of feeding 50 truck drivers parked end to end along the Summerland Way during the peak of the flood emergency The Campbell family  beef cattle producers from Lawrence made it to town for the first time after being flooded into their home They're now re-stocking the freezer and buying up school supplies in case another deluge confines them to their farm again It has been an adventure of sorts for 12 year old Chloe and 10 year old Georgia who've been riding their horses and using the tinny and kayak to visit neighbours Their mum Wendy remembers fondly the times of flood when she was a child and is trying to replicate those memories for her kids Meanwhile the Clarence Vally Mayor Richie Williamson does the round of media interviews Floods across four states have saturated the start of 2011 The road infrastructure bill for the Clarence sits at about eight million dollars The cost to farmers and the tourism industry have yet to be calculated Many locals have already made claims for Government assistance  And there is a simple environment equation after a mayor flood Summer heat plus flood waters typically equals a fish kill Natural resource management staff from several Government agencies are monitoring water quality amid reports of dead fish in the Clarence It may be that the worst is still to come The Clarence River Historical Society hopes to make the most of the current flood focus They're rushing to finalise a book that documents the Clarence River floods from the 1800 to the present day Compiler Hazel Ford says I need a flood to launch it and here we are working frantically to get it all together It should be printed an available from the historical society by the end of the month Join the community conversation via the ABC North Coast Facebook page  And if you have images from this latest flood upload them to the ABC North Coast Flickr page and we'll feature them on our website If you or someone you know is experiencing emotional stress as a result of the flooding you can call Lifeline to speak with a crisis counsellor 13 11 14

Words: The Jeparit community has spent the day madly sandbagging ready for the rush of water down the Wimmera River but they're mostly concerned about the town levee Modelling shows that the levee is insufficient with a one in 100 year flood and what went through Horsham was a one in 200 year event so they're saying the levee is going to fail in any case he said today So our resources are being spent on sandbagging property and pretend the levee isn't there Several residents said they wished the Shire was allowed to strengthen the levee similar to Warracknabeal where a resident is credited with saving the town from signficant flood after he established a six kilometre temporary levee They should've got the machines out and built them up The did it in Warracknabeal and I can't see why they can't save Jeparit said local resident Yvonne But the State Emergency Service has warned people to think very carefully before constructing their own levee warning that if there dire consequences they could be called before the coroner In the meantime Jeparit has spent the day manually filling thousands of sandbags and protecting homes near the river bank The town popular and well known museum has been packed up into shipping containers and moved to higher ground with historic vehicles and farm machinery     Jeparit prepares for the flood water from the Wimmera River

Title: Floods devastate rural farms
Primary image caption: The floods have washed away fences in western Victoria, making it difficult for farmers to contain livestock.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Rural | Byline: Laura Poole
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Rural:Agricultural Crops:Grain, Rural:Agricultural Crops:Wheat, Rural:Crop Harvesting
Keywords: vicfloods, flooding, floods, charlton, farming, rural, coonooer, bridge
Words: Floodwaters have swept up livestock carrying sheep more than a kilometre upstream Merinos that survived the floods now have flystrike where maggots eat their flesh Some grain crops yet to be harvested are ruined others will be downgraded to livestock feed quality Wet hay bales are at risk of spontaneous combustion Livestock losses At Coonooer Bridge south of Charlton farmers are only now coming to terms with their huge losses a week after the Avoca River flooded Mixed farmer Aaron Sanderson is finding dead sheep caught under fences pushed over in the floods He says he still doesn't know how many have died It hard to actually know exactly until I put them in the yards and get an exact number We are still finding dead sheep but it hard to get a gauge because they're swept up away We've found some that were four paddocks away probably 15 kilometres away that had got washed away Once the floodwaters subside there are new challenges for livestock farmers Securing sheep without fences is one problem Battling flystrike is another Mr Sanderson says he lost many kilometres of fencing He had to move his 2500 mob of merino sheep 25 kilometres to his higher ground that still has fences He is treating sheep for flystrike The flies are our biggest drama at the moment It a phenomenal amount of body strike they're getting Mr Sanderson says he been so busy he hasn't had to time to reflect on what he lost It probably going to hit in in the next few days Ruined hay grain The Watts have farmed at Coonooer Bridge for six generations but no one in the family has ever experienced a flood this big Their farm house flooded as did their farm yard including machinery sheds hay sheds and grain storage silos Family and friends are working quickly trying to separate wet and dry hay bales The Watts had three hay sheds filled with 9000 bales of hay Alistair Watts estimates 2000 could be ruined He worried the moist bales could spontaneously combust so they're moving the bales from the sheds to the middle of a paddock We're trying to save some of the hay bales before they catch on fire The water was a third of the way up the large square bales It soaked into them a fair bit

Words: As flood waters reach their slow and steady peak in Horsham ABC Local Cross-Media reporter Tim Gerritsen has been on the ground He spoke to Rob Pyers the Principal of Dimboola Memorial Secondary College who has been sitting out the agonising wait in Horsham as he helps to defend his parents property there From my point of view I'd rather it sort of be there and done with and move on as quickly as it could Rob Pyer father who is on a respirator has been sent over to his own house in Dimboola; this house is itself waiting for the flooded Wimmera river to hit Fortunately the house is on high ground - and therefore not likely to be affected by the floods - although according to Mr Pyers it is hard to know I personally can't see where all this water is going to go     Dimboola resident Rob Pyers talks about what to come

Title: The destruction of Carisbrook
Primary image caption: Aerial view of Carisbrook, central Victoria, Friday January 14, 2011.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Victorian State Emergency Service | Byline:
Subjects: Disasters and Accidents:Floods,
Keywords: carisbrook, floods, photos, ABC, news
Words: The town of Carisbrook lies in ruins following record-smashing floodwaters surging through its streets Within hours the situation had been deemed catastrophic and locals were being evacuated from the town as nearby reservoirs filled up and their spillways gushed water into surrounding catchments Roads and bridges were critically damaged with critical warnings issued about the dangers inherent in returning to flood damaged homes On Saturday and Sunday locals returned to their historic town to begin the heart-breaking job of cleaning out their homes and disposing of their ruined belongings; the cleanup and reconstruction will take weeks before the town infrastructure is back to normal     ABC Rural reporter Caleb Cluff reports from the aftermath in Carisbrook

Title: We won't let our town die: Carisbrook resident
Primary image caption: Carisbrook family Rose, Chris and Jan clean out their home.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Ballarat | Byline: Margaret Burin
Subjects: Community and Society, Disasters and Accidents:Floods,
Keywords: carisbrook, victoria, floods, flooding, abc, margaret burin
Words: Almost every house and business in town was flooded Flood waters more than two feet high swept through Jan Galloway home; destroying furnishings the kitchen electrical goods and many personal items She says the damage would be worth thousands of dollars Everyone in the whole community down on this flat part of Carisbrook has been affected just the same way you know lost all of their furnishings floor coverings However Jan and her family are choosing to look on the bright side We're not too badly off; some of the people have lost a lot of stuff Amazingly we had photo albums like our wedding photo album it fallen apart but we've got all the photos Jan says there have been lots of calls from people offering to help People have just been amazing they've turned up to help and clean all the stuff up out of the house Caroline Colonial Restaurant owner Michael Turton says the building established in 1853 was the town first grocery store and it has recovered from several disasters They had a fire here in 1937 which almost gutted the shop and there still parts of the building that are original blue stone and they built it up from that in 1937 and I'll bloody build up from that now You're not going to let your town die no way     Caroline Colonial Restaurant at Carisbrook owner Michael Turton

Title: Skipton community comes together for cleanup

Keywords: skipton, floods, abc, margaret burin, cleanup, flooding, victorian
Words: Many of those whose homes and shops were flooded in September last year are back at square one of the recovery process Juli Davine only reopened Skipton Art Gallery a month ago Now the building and most of the art work has been destroyed all over again This time it much worse Last time we managed to put all the artwork in the gallery up and saved all of it This time we've lost 90 per cent of it she says We've lost walls the floor gone yet again Juli says people from around the community including local artists have volunteered their time to clean out the gallery The fact that so many people turned up to help and the shire have been excellent and put up protective fencing is just amazing Torrents of water down the Emu Creek ripped down Skipton old wooden footbridge which was built in 1931 and ran alongside the town main bridge along the Glenelg Highway The remnants lie on the creek banks This second disaster in less than four months has made this already tight-knit community even closer While many of Skipton men were helping clean floor coverings and move furniture inside the local pub local women have been scrubbing glasses and kitchenware so that the heart of the town can get back up-and-running as soon as possible     The Skipton community gets scrubbing after the floods

Title: South East flooding update: Naracoorte and Frances
Primary image caption: Creeks around Naracoorte rose on Friday - almost totally covering this mural.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: User Submitted | Byline: Peter Little
Subjects: Community and Society:Community Organisations, Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Incidents, Disasters and Accidents:Emergency Planning, Disasters and Accidents:Floods
Keywords: rain, water, flooding, south east, frances, hotel, peter little, weather
Words: Following warnings at the end of last week the State Emergency Service and Country Fire Service advise that a community safety warning is no longer in place for the Naracoorte area Local emergency crews continue to monitor the situation and updated information will be provided as it becomes available Residents are advised that a community safety warning will be issued should the current situation change Residents are asked to listen to the advice and instruction given by the emergency services and local authorities A community safety warning was issued late on Friday afternoon due to significant rainfall both locally and through Victoria Precautionary measures were taken and sandbagging occurred last night and in the early hours of Saturday morning prior to the water levels beginning to recede A community meeting was held on Saturday night in the Naracoorte Town Hall Smith Street Naracoorte The SES and CFS advises people in this area to take sensible precautions including Take proactive measures such as securing their property and valuables Never drive in flood waters Be aware that roads may be treacherous and impassable due to flooding and always obey road closure signs If stranded stay with your vehicle Never enter flood waters and in particular do not allow children to play in or near them Stay tuned to local radio for current weather advice and warnings and follow directions from local authorities People in this area need to be aware that drinking water may be contaminated by flood waters If in doubt boil water prior to consumption If inundation has or is likely to occur turn off all power sources such as gas and electricity and do not turn anything on again until you are sure it is safe to do so Frances flooding On Saturday morning floodwaters started to recede in South Australia South East after some Heavy rain at the end of last week saw water up to a metre deep in parts of Frances The State Emergency Service says it continuing to monitor the situation but floodwater alerts are no longer in place Floodwaters from Victoria also caused a local creek to overflow temporarily cutting off the town to traffic Incident controller Bret Merritt explained that the Country Fire Service will continue to monitor water levels in the area It feeding into a number of systems the water from both Frances and other areas just across the border but Frances is our first township it impinging on so the Naracoorte Creek Mosquito Creek and Morambro Creek areas are the ones that we believe the water is going to flow in he said Local publican Terry Austin says his hotel was flooded when the creek overflowed on Thursday night The whole street just started to flood and it just snowballed and it was going everywhere to every house in the town he said They had all the pumps going and it just wasn't keeping up it unbelievable how quickly it can flood and I was knee-deep in water around the hotel More than 200 homes and businesses in the Riverland and South East were damaged by the flooding Emergency service personnel sandbagged buildings and pumped water from properties in towns across both regions Photos Photos were sent to us from South East photographer Peter Little He says  I went out to Frances on Friday morning following heavy rain and have attached a couple of photos you may enjoy an enormous area under water around the town with a lot of bridges leading in and out of Frances being affected by the downpour Of Naracoorte he explains The creek appears to have dropped overnight however some businesses took the precaution of sandbagging

Title: Flood damage won't stop the Tenterfield Show
Primary image caption: A mess made of the footbridge across the creek
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Tenterfield Show Society | Byline: Bruce Petrie
Subjects: Community and Society, Disasters and Accidents, Disasters and Accidents:Floods, Rural
Station: ABC New England North West NSW
Keywords: tenterfield show, floods, peter petty
Words: Tenterfield is gearing up for its February show despite damage to the showground from recent floods Some parts of the town received 254mm of rain last week and the Tenterfield Creek which runs through the town inundated at least four bridges The showgrounds are also located either side of the creek and Peter Petty the Show Society President says there was not much notice as the floodwaters came through Mr Petty says there has been significant damage to the shearing complex where competitions are staged and wool displayed at show time It in this exhibition space schools display their fine arts as well The damage is indicative of the force of the water It a fairly big building about 60-70metres long it suffered major damage like all the cement floor was lifted and it got some very big sliding doors that got major damage to them says Peter The shearing complex is on the southern side of the showground there holes and that over there you'd fit vehicles in it just taken big divots out of the ground And on the southern side right against the building it like a small swimming pool area Last week a taxi driver told ABC local radio a piano was seen floating in the floodwaters Peter says that out of the shearing complex It ended up at Shirley Park which is about a kilometre away It was standing upright too just like you could open it up and play it he says The cleanup for the February Show has begun about 45 people turned up to a working bee last Saturday Half of them I didn't even know just towns folk and it was just so good and we got so much done pulled fences back up and picked up debris and just done a general tidy up he says Cancelling the show was not an option and another working bee will continue the clean up this Saturday Anyone wanting to help can phone the local show office on 6736 1464 The show is set down for the first weekend in February Peter says there will be no shearing competition and no cattle stud program but everything else will be business as usual
